1087010.1007/10870.1572-8854Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-014-0512-851210.1007/s10870-014-0512-8Original PaperSyntheses, Characterization and Crystal Structures of Three New Copper(II) Complexes Based on N,N′-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane and Three Different Aromatic DicarboxylatesLinHong-Yan1aLuanJian1HanNa1LiuGuo-Cheng1grid.440654.7Department of ChemistryBohai University121000JinzhouPeople’s Republic of China+86-416-3400308+86-416-3400308linhongyan_2005@126.com274201452014445279286124201433201412420142742014© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20142014Abstract

Three new copper(II) complexes based on the flexible N,N’-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) and three different aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)], [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]·H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 2 D grid polymeric layer constructed by the [Cu-4-dpyb] chains and [Cu-5-MIP] chains, and the adjacent layers are further linked by hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 3 D supramolecular structure. Complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on the polymer chain [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n, in which the discrete 4-dpyb ligands are dispersed. Complex 3 represents a polymer chain based on the μ4-bridging 4-dpyb ligand, in which 2,6-PDA only serves as a terminal chelating ligand. For complex 3, the neighboring chains are extended into a 3 D supramolecular structure by hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking interactions. In these complexes, the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands 4-dpyb show the μ2-bridging mode (for 1), non-coordinated mode (for 2) and μ4-bridging mode (for 3), respectively, and three kinds of aromatic dicarboxylate anions (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) also adopt three different coordination modes. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes. In addition, the thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of complexes 1–3 have also been investigated.

Graphical Abstract

Three new 3 D supramolecular complexes based on 2 D polymer layers or 1 D chains, [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]·H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes.

The rational design of transition metal complexes is of great importance for developing new crystalline materials owing to their intriguing architectures and topologies as well as their potential applications in gas storage/separation, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism [1–4]. Although a lot of such complexes have been prepared by the hydrothermal self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands, the controlled syntheses of these complexes are still facing many challenges due to many factors affecting the crystallization and structural construction in the hydrothermal conditions, such as organic ligands, reactants ratios, systematic pH values and reaction temperatures etc. [5–8]. Thereinto, organic ligands as bridging linkers are of the most critical factor for the formation of complexes because they greatly affect the coordination frameworks and specific topologies [9–11].

In the recent years, the employment of mixed ligands including neutral N-donor and anionic O-donor ligands has gradually become an effective approach [6, 12–15]. The flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand has been proved to be an excellent choice of the neutral N-donor ligand, by combining it with O-donor carboxylates ligands, a series of coordination complexes with diversified structures and interesting properties have been successfully prepared [16–19]. For example, Chen’s group has reported four new Ni(II) coordination complexes based on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands (N,N′-di(4-pyridyl)-adipoamide and N,N′-di(4-pyridyl)suberoamide) and three different bridging dicarboxylates, and all of the complexes exhibit various magnetic behaviors [18]. More recently, using the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand 3-dpyb (N,N′-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane), we have obtained a novel 3 D coordination complex, [Cu3(3-dpyb)(1,2-BDC)2(μ2-OH)2], which exhibits good photocatalytic activity for the degradation of methylene blue (MB) [19].

As an extension of our study on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands [19–22], in this work, we selected N,N′-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) containing the flexible amide-(CH2)4-bridging group as the main ligand based on the following consideration: Its backbone -(CH2)4- can bend to satisfy the coordination requirements of metal centers, and its amide groups can provide additional coordination sites, which may lead to form intriguing coordination frameworks. In addition, the amide groups of 4-dpyb may be regarded as hydrogen bonding acceptors/or donors for building supramolecular networks. To our knowledge, the coordination complexes based on the mixed ligands of 4-dpyb and aromatic dicarboxylates have not been found up to now. So we introduce three aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)] into the copper(II)-4-dpyb system and generate three new complexes [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]·H2O (3). The thermal stabilities and the fluorescent properties of the three complexes have been examined.

Experimental SectionMaterials and Methods

All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand 4-dpyb was prepared according to the reported literature [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Varian FT-IR 640 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) data for the complexes 1–3 were performed on a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence/phosphorescence spectrophotometer.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of CuCl2·3H2O (0.051 g, 0.3 mmol), 4-dpyb (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), 5-H2MIP (0.027 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (12 mL) and NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 4 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: ca. 25 % based on Cu). Anal. for C25H28CuN4O8: calcd. C 52.08, H 4.90, N 9.72; found C 52.01, H 4.93, N 9.76 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3388 w, 3284 w, 3070 w, 2928 w, 1653 s, 1617 s, 1572 s, 1547 s, 1497 m, 1420 m, 1353 s, 1224 m, 1194 w, 1107 s, 1071 m, 1024 w, 980 w, 858 s, 773 s, 727 s, 622 m, 519 w.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

The synthesis method of 2 is similar to that of 1 except for ligand 5-H2AIP (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2MIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: ca. 33 % based on Cu). Anal. for C32H30CuN6O10: calcd. C 53.17, H 4.19, N 11.63; found C 53.19, H 4.15, N 11.60 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3373 m, 3278 m, 3079 w, 2938 w, 1711 m, 1628 s, 1614 s, 1567 s, 1541 s, 1478 m, 1429 m, 1380 s, 1368 m, 1327 m, 1214 m, 1186 m, 1077 m, 1048 m, 1025 w, 933 w, 868 s, 781 s, 715 s, 634 m, 522 w.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)<sub>0.5</sub>(2,6-PDA)]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

The synthesis method of 3 is similar to that of 2 except for ligand 2,6-H2PDA (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2AIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.016 g, 0.40 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 3 were obtained (yield: ca. 37 % based on Cu). Anal. for C15H14CuN3O6: Calcd. C 45.47, H 3.57, N 10.61; found C 45.41, H 3.59, N 10.67 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3428 w, 3081 w, 2948 w, 1658 m, 1622 s, 1672 w, 1430 m, 1367 s, 1349 m, 1298 w, 1107 s, 912 w, 859 m, 786 s, 737 m, 620 s, 525 w.

X-Ray Crystallographic Study

X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1–3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω and θ scan mode. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package [24, 25]. All non-hydrogen atoms were found and refined with anisotropic factors. The hydrogen atoms of the 4-dpyb ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. For complexes 2 and 3, carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C11 and C11′ in 2, C8 and C8′ in 3) were disordered. The hydrogen atoms of the incompletely deprotonated carboxyl groups for 5-HAIP anions in 2 and the hydrogen atoms of some carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C10, C11, C11′ in 2, C7, C8, C8′ in 3) could not be located, but were directly included in the final molecular formula. A summary of crystal data and structure refinements for three complexes was provided in Table 1. The coordination modes of copper(II) ions and ligands in complexes 1–3 were listed in Table 2. Selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table 3. CCDC reference numbers are 980117 (1), 968009 (2) and 980116 (3), respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on a 2 D grid coordination polymer layer composed of bridging ligands 4-dpyb and 5-MIP. As illustrated in Fig. 1a, Cu1 ion is five-coordinated and adopts a distorted tetragonal pyramid geometry, being ligated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two 4-dpyb ligands with bond distances of 2.051(2) Å [Cu1–N1, Cu1–N2] and N1–Cu1–N2 angle of 175.07(8) °, three oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups of two 5-MIP anions and a coordinated water molecule [the bond lengths of Cu1–O range from 1.9506(16) to 2.2540(19) Å]. In complex 1, both carboxyl groups of the 5-H2MIP ligand are deprotonated and link two Cu(II) ions with monodentate coordination mode (see Table 2), which leads to the formation of a [Cu-5-MIP] linear chain. The μ2-bridging 4-dpyb ligands display two kinds of conformations (Table 2), which bridge two Cu(II) ions to build a [Cu-4-dpyb] chain with the non-bonding Cu···Cu distances of 20.191 Å (A-type) and 18.099 Å (B-type). The two pyridyl rings are parallel for 4-dpyb ligand. Two kinds of 4-dpyb ligands alternately connected the Cu(II) ions belonging to the adjacent [Cu-5-MIP] chains to construct a 2 D polymer layer, as shown in Fig. 1b. In 1, each Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four organic ligands (two 4-dpyb and two 5-MIP) and can simply be considered as a 4-connected node. Each 4-dpyb or 5-MIP ligating with two Cu(II) ions only can be regarded as a linear linker. Therefore, the 2 D network of 1 can be described as a well-known (4,4)-grid layer (Fig. 1c).

The adjacent layers of 1 are extended to a 3 D supramolecular network by O–H···O and N–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions, as shown in Fig. 1d. The O–H···O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the coordinated water molecule O(1 W) and carbonyl oxygen atom O5 of 4-dpyb ligand [O1 W…O5 = 2.801(3) Å]. The N–H···O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the N4 atom from amide group and the carboxyl O2 atom with N4···O2 distance of 3.176(3) Å.

Crystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)<sub>2</sub>] <bold>(2)</bold>

X-ray analysis shows that complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network constructed from the polymeric chains [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n and discrete 4-dpyb ligands. The fundamental building unit of 2 is composed of one crystallographically independent Cu(II) ion, a discrete 4-dpyb ligand and a 5-HAIP anion. The coordination environment of Cu1 ion is shown in Fig. 2a. The Cu1 ion is tetra-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two amino groups of two 5-HAIP ligands, and two oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups belonging to two different 5-HAIP ligands, completing a quadrangle style. The bond distances and angles around the Cu1 are 1.904(2) Å for Cu1–O1 (Cu1–O1#1), 2.078(3) Å for Cu1–N1#2 (Cu1–N1#3), 180.0° for O1–Cu1–O1#1 (N1#2–Cu1–N1#3) and 88.26(10) – 91.74(10) ° for O–Cu1–N, respectively. So it is noted the O1–N1#2–Cu1–O1#1–N1#3 five-member unit is obviously perfectly planar.

The 5-H2AIP ligand, as a dicarboxylate, possesses multiple potential coordination sites involving two carboxyl groups and one amino group, which may be more conducive to coordinate with metal ions in the metal–organic coordination frameworks. In addition, the 5-H2AIP could serve as hydrogen bonding donors or acceptors to build high-dimensional supramolecular networks. Recently, the 5-H2AIP ligand has been used as an auxiliary ligand combining with various N-donor ligands to construct intriguing structures and novel topologies [26, 27]. For example, Zheng’s group has obtained a 2 D (4,4) network [Co(5-AIP)(bix)]·H2O (bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl-methylene)-benzene), which shows a twofold parallel interpenetrating 2 D→2 D structure, and features a twofold interpenetrating cds hydrogen bonding network [28]. Our group has reported two 2 D metal–organic frameworks [Cu(3-dpye)0.5(5-AIP)(H2O)] and [Cu(3-dpyh)0.5(5-AIP)(H2O)] [3-dpye = N,N′-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,2-ethane, 3-dpyb = 3-dpyh = N,N′-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,6-hexane], in which two carboxyl groups and one amino group of 5-AIP ligand coordinate to the Cu(II) ions with a tri(monodentate) coordination mode [19]. While in this paper, the ligand 5-HAIP displays a bis(monodentate) bridging mode in complex 2 (Table 2): its amino group and one carboxyl group are simultaneously coordinated with Cu(II) ions, while another carboxyl group is protonated. The adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by the bridging 5-HAIP ligands to form a polymeric chain, as shown in Fig. 2b. The ligand 4-dpyb is not coordinated to Cu(II) ion (Table 2), which is different from that in complex 1. The π–π stacking interactions among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.61 Å, as well as the N–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions between the nitrogen atom of amino group from 5-HAIP ligand and the carbonyl O5 atom of 4-dpyb ligand [N1…O5 = 2.955(5) Å] result in a 3 D supramolecular framework of complex 2 (see Fig. 2c).

Crystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)<sub>0.5</sub>(2,6-PDA)]·H<sub>2</sub>O <bold>(3)</bold>

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 3 consists of one Cu(II) ion, half a 4-dpyb ligand, one 2,6-PDA anion and one lattice water molecule. The Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a 2,6-PDA anion, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from one 4-dpyb ligand, and one carbonyl oxygen atom from another 4-dpyb ligand to give a CuO3N2 square-pyramidal arrangement [Cu1–O1 = 2.021(2), Cu1–O2 = 2.015(3), Cu1–O5 = 2.448(2), Cu1–N1 = 1.958(3), and Cu1–N2 = 1.896(3) Å], as shown in Fig. 3a. Each 2,6-PDA anion coordinates to one Cu(II) ion in a chelating coordination mode (Table 2). Then the Cu(II) ions are connected by 4-dpyb ligand with a μ4-bridging coordination mode (Table 2) to build a chain-like structure in complex 3 (Fig. 3b). The adjacent chains are packed into a 2 D supramolecular structure by π-π stacking interaction among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.69Å. Finally, the neighboring supramolecular layers are linked by the hydrogen bonding interactions to construct a 3 D supramolecular network. The C–H···O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the carbon atom (C11) from 2,6-PDA and the oxygen atom O3 from carboxyl group of 2,6-PDA with C(11)–H(11A)···O(3) distance of 3.266 Å.

Thermal Properties

To estimate the stabilities of complexes 1–3, TG analyses are performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in the temperature range of 30–700 °C, as shown in Fig. 4. The TG curves of complexes 1 and 3 show two weight loss steps. The first one should be assigned to the loss of water molecules 6.7 % (calcd. 6.3 %) in 1 and 4.7 % (calcd. 4.6 %) in 3. The second one occurs about 275 °C for 1 and 260 °C for 3, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of the organic ligands. The remaining weight 13.7 % for 1 or 19.6 % for 3 is in agreement with the percentage of Cu and O components (calcd.: 13.9 % for 1, 20.2 % for 3), which suggests that the final product is CuO. For complex 2, the TG curve only exhibits one obvious weight loss step. This weight loss observed at 315 °C may be attributed to the loss of the ligands 4-dpyb and 5-HAIP. The weight loss 88.6 % corresponds to the calculated value 88.9 %. The remaining weight 11.4 % is in agreement with the percentage 11.1 % of Cu and O components, implying that CuO is the thermal decomposition product of complex 2.

Fluorescent Properties

Recently, the fluorescent properties of a variety of transition metal complexes have been reported. The copper(II) complexes do not contain d10 metal centers, but a series of fluorescent copper(II) complexes have been reported [29, 30]. In order to investigate the potential applications of complexes 1–3, we have measured the fluorescent properties of complexes 1–3 in the solid state at room temperature. To understand the nature of these emission bands, we also examined the fluorescent behavior of the free 4-dpyb ligand. As shown in Fig. 5, the free 4-dpyb ligand displays a maximum fluorescent emission at 398 nm (λex = 320 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π–π* transitions. For complexes 1–3, upon excitation at 320 nm, the fluorescent emissions are observed at 395 nm for 1, 398 nm for 2, and 403 nm for 3, respectively. Compared with the 4-dpyb ligand, it is clear that a 3 nm blue-shift for 1 and a 5 nm red-shift for 3 can be observed, respectively. Similar to the reported copper(II) complexes with N-donor ligands, these phenomena may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition [19]. While the fluorescent emission of complex 2 is the same as the free 4-dpyb ligand, which may be due to the non-coordination mode of 4-dpyb in 2. The differences of fluorescent behaviors for complexes 1–3 are probably caused by the different coordination environment of Cu(II) ions with 4-dpyb ligands and final supramolecular structures of three complexes.

Conclusion

In summary, three new copper(II) coordination complexes constructed by the flexible 4-dpyb ligand and three different aromatic dicarboxylates (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) have been hydrothermally synthesized, which represent examples of structural changes from a 2 D coordination polymeric network (for 1) to two kinds of chain-like structures (for 2 and 3). In complexes 1 and 3, the 4-dpyb serving as bridging ligands adopt the μ2- and the μ4-bridging coordination modes, respectively. While in 2, the 4-dpyb is not coordinated with Cu(II) ion. The results indicate that the different coordination modes of the flexible 4-dpyb ligands and three aromatic dicarboxylate anions play important roles in governing the final polymeric structures. These preliminary results in this work imply that the title complexes may be potential candidates for fluorescent materials.

elements.clean_text: ]>This XML was provided by Springer Naturedoi:10.1007/s10870-014-0512-831aa4ebcea41b6792ab66adebe5119a0/kaist-api111011087010.1007/10870.1572-8854Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-014-0512-851210.1007/s10870-014-0512-8Original PaperSyntheses, Characterization and Crystal Structures of Three New Copper(II) Complexes Based on N,N'-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane and Three Different Aromatic DicarboxylatesLinHong-Yan1aLuanJian1HanNa1LiuGuo-Cheng11grid.440654.7Department of ChemistryBohai University121000JinzhouPeople's Republic of Chinaa+86-416-3400308+86-416-3400308linhongyan_2005@126.com274201452014445279286124201433201412420142742014© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20142014AbstractThree new copper(II) complexes based on the flexible N,N'-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) and three different aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)], [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 2 D grid polymeric layer constructed by the [Cu-4-dpyb] chains and [Cu-5-MIP] chains, and the adjacent layers are further linked by hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 3 D supramolecular structure. Complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on the polymer chain [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n, in which the discrete 4-dpyb ligands are dispersed. Complex 3 represents a polymer chain based on the μ4-bridging 4-dpyb ligand, in which 2,6-PDA only serves as a terminal chelating ligand. For complex 3, the neighboring chains are extended into a 3 D supramolecular structure by hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking interactions. In these complexes, the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands 4-dpyb show the μ2-bridging mode (for 1), non-coordinated mode (for 2) and μ4-bridging mode (for 3), respectively, and three kinds of aromatic dicarboxylate anions (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) also adopt three different coordination modes. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes. In addition, the thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of complexes 1-3 have also been investigated.Graphical AbstractThree new 3 D supramolecular complexes based on 2 D polymer layers or 1 D chains, [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes. KeywordsHydrothermally synthesisCopper(II) complexBis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligandDicarboxylic acidFluorescent propertiespublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count12issue-article-count7issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2014issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media New Yorkissue-copyright-year2014article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2014article-registration-date-month4article-registration-date-day12article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2014_Article_512.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2014issue-online-date-month5issue-online-date-day3issue-print-date-year2014issue-print-date-month5issue-print-date-day2issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryCrystallographyjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseIntroductionThe rational design of transition metal complexes is of great importance for developing new crystalline materials owing to their intriguing architectures and topologies as well as their potential applications in gas storage/separation, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism [1-4]. Although a lot of such complexes have been prepared by the hydrothermal self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands, the controlled syntheses of these complexes are still facing many challenges due to many factors affecting the crystallization and structural construction in the hydrothermal conditions, such as organic ligands, reactants ratios, systematic pH values and reaction temperatures etc. [5-8]. Thereinto, organic ligands as bridging linkers are of the most critical factor for the formation of complexes because they greatly affect the coordination frameworks and specific topologies [9-11].In the recent years, the employment of mixed ligands including neutral N-donor and anionic O-donor ligands has gradually become an effective approach [6, 12-15]. The flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand has been proved to be an excellent choice of the neutral N-donor ligand, by combining it with O-donor carboxylates ligands, a series of coordination complexes with diversified structures and interesting properties have been successfully prepared [16-19]. For example, Chen's group has reported four new Ni(II) coordination complexes based on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands (N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-adipoamide and N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)suberoamide) and three different bridging dicarboxylates, and all of the complexes exhibit various magnetic behaviors [18]. More recently, using the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand 3-dpyb (N,N'-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane), we have obtained a novel 3 D coordination complex, [Cu3(3-dpyb)(1,2-BDC)2(μ2-OH)2], which exhibits good photocatalytic activity for the degradation of methylene blue (MB) [19].As an extension of our study on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands [19-22], in this work, we selected N,N'-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) containing the flexible amide-(CH2)4-bridging group as the main ligand based on the following consideration: Its backbone -(CH2)4- can bend to satisfy the coordination requirements of metal centers, and its amide groups can provide additional coordination sites, which may lead to form intriguing coordination frameworks. In addition, the amide groups of 4-dpyb may be regarded as hydrogen bonding acceptors/or donors for building supramolecular networks. To our knowledge, the coordination complexes based on the mixed ligands of 4-dpyb and aromatic dicarboxylates have not been found up to now. So we introduce three aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)] into the copper(II)-4-dpyb system and generate three new complexes [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3). The thermal stabilities and the fluorescent properties of the three complexes have been examined.Experimental SectionMaterials and MethodsAll reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand 4-dpyb was prepared according to the reported literature [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Varian FT-IR 640 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) data for the complexes 1-3 were performed on a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence/phosphorescence spectrophotometer.Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1)A mixture of CuCl2⋅3H2O (0.051 g, 0.3 mmol), 4-dpyb (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), 5-H2MIP (0.027 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (12 mL) and NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 4 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: ca. 25 % based on Cu). Anal. for C25H28CuN4O8: calcd. C 52.08, H 4.90, N 9.72; found C 52.01, H 4.93, N 9.76 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3388 w, 3284 w, 3070 w, 2928 w, 1653 s, 1617 s, 1572 s, 1547 s, 1497 m, 1420 m, 1353 s, 1224 m, 1194 w, 1107 s, 1071 m, 1024 w, 980 w, 858 s, 773 s, 727 s, 622 m, 519 w.Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2)The synthesis method of 2 is similar to that of 1 except for ligand 5-H2AIP (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2MIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: ca. 33 % based on Cu). Anal. for C32H30CuN6O10: calcd. C 53.17, H 4.19, N 11.63; found C 53.19, H 4.15, N 11.60 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3373 m, 3278 m, 3079 w, 2938 w, 1711 m, 1628 s, 1614 s, 1567 s, 1541 s, 1478 m, 1429 m, 1380 s, 1368 m, 1327 m, 1214 m, 1186 m, 1077 m, 1048 m, 1025 w, 933 w, 868 s, 781 s, 715 s, 634 m, 522 w.Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3)The synthesis method of 3 is similar to that of 2 except for ligand 2,6-H2PDA (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2AIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.016 g, 0.40 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 3 were obtained (yield: ca. 37 % based on Cu). Anal. for C15H14CuN3O6: Calcd. C 45.47, H 3.57, N 10.61; found C 45.41, H 3.59, N 10.67 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3428 w, 3081 w, 2948 w, 1658 m, 1622 s, 1672 w, 1430 m, 1367 s, 1349 m, 1298 w, 1107 s, 912 w, 859 m, 786 s, 737 m, 620 s, 525 w.X-Ray Crystallographic StudyX-ray diffraction data for complexes 1-3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω and θ scan mode. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package [24, 25]. All non-hydrogen atoms were found and refined with anisotropic factors. The hydrogen atoms of the 4-dpyb ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. For complexes 2 and 3, carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C11 and C11' in 2, C8 and C8' in 3) were disordered. The hydrogen atoms of the incompletely deprotonated carboxyl groups for 5-HAIP anions in 2 and the hydrogen atoms of some carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C10, C11, C11' in 2, C7, C8, C8' in 3) could not be located, but were directly included in the final molecular formula. A summary of crystal data and structure refinements for three complexes was provided in Table 1. The coordination modes of copper(II) ions and ligands in complexes 1-3 were listed in Table 2. Selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table 3. CCDC reference numbers are 980117 (1), 968009 (2) and 980116 (3), respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1)Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on a 2 D grid coordination polymer layer composed of bridging ligands 4-dpyb and 5-MIP. As illustrated in Fig. 1a, Cu1 ion is five-coordinated and adopts a distorted tetragonal pyramid geometry, being ligated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two 4-dpyb ligands with bond distances of 2.051(2) Å [Cu1-N1, Cu1-N2] and N1-Cu1-N2 angle of 175.07(8) °, three oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups of two 5-MIP anions and a coordinated water molecule [the bond lengths of Cu1-O range from 1.9506(16) to 2.2540(19) Å]. In complex 1, both carboxyl groups of the 5-H2MIP ligand are deprotonated and link two Cu(II) ions with monodentate coordination mode (see Table 2), which leads to the formation of a [Cu-5-MIP] linear chain. The μ2-bridging 4-dpyb ligands display two kinds of conformations (Table 2), which bridge two Cu(II) ions to build a [Cu-4-dpyb] chain with the non-bonding Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances of 20.191 Å (A-type) and 18.099 Å (B-type). The two pyridyl rings are parallel for 4-dpyb ligand. Two kinds of 4-dpyb ligands alternately connected the Cu(II) ions belonging to the adjacent [Cu-5-MIP] chains to construct a 2 D polymer layer, as shown in Fig. 1b. In 1, each Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four organic ligands (two 4-dpyb and two 5-MIP) and can simply be considered as a 4-connected node. Each 4-dpyb or 5-MIP ligating with two Cu(II) ions only can be regarded as a linear linker. Therefore, the 2 D network of 1 can be described as a well-known (4,4)-grid layer (Fig. 1c).The adjacent layers of 1 are extended to a 3 D supramolecular network by O-H⋅⋅⋅O and N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions, as shown in Fig. 1d. The O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the coordinated water molecule O(1 W) and carbonyl oxygen atom O5 of 4-dpyb ligand [O1 W…O5 = 2.801(3) Å]. The N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the N4 atom from amide group and the carboxyl O2 atom with N4⋅⋅⋅O2 distance of 3.176(3) Å.Crystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2)X-ray analysis shows that complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network constructed from the polymeric chains [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n and discrete 4-dpyb ligands. The fundamental building unit of 2 is composed of one crystallographically independent Cu(II) ion, a discrete 4-dpyb ligand and a 5-HAIP anion. The coordination environment of Cu1 ion is shown in Fig. 2a. The Cu1 ion is tetra-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two amino groups of two 5-HAIP ligands, and two oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups belonging to two different 5-HAIP ligands, completing a quadrangle style. The bond distances and angles around the Cu1 are 1.904(2) Å for Cu1-O1 (Cu1-O1#1), 2.078(3) Å for Cu1-N1#2 (Cu1-N1#3), 180.0° for O1-Cu1-O1#1 (N1#2-Cu1-N1#3) and 88.26(10) - 91.74(10) ° for O-Cu1-N, respectively. So it is noted the O1-N1#2-Cu1-O1#1-N1#3 five-member unit is obviously perfectly planar.The 5-H2AIP ligand, as a dicarboxylate, possesses multiple potential coordination sites involving two carboxyl groups and one amino group, which may be more conducive to coordinate with metal ions in the metal-organic coordination frameworks. In addition, the 5-H2AIP could serve as hydrogen bonding donors or acceptors to build high-dimensional supramolecular networks. Recently, the 5-H2AIP ligand has been used as an auxiliary ligand combining with various N-donor ligands to construct intriguing structures and novel topologies [26, 27]. For example, Zheng's group has obtained a 2 D (4,4) network [Co(5-AIP)(bix)]⋅H2O (bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl-methylene)-benzene), which shows a twofold parallel interpenetrating 2 D→2 D structure, and features a twofold interpenetrating cds hydrogen bonding network [28]. Our group has reported two 2 D metal-organic frameworks [Cu(3-dpye)0.5(5-AIP)(H2O)] and [Cu(3-dpyh)0.5(5-AIP)(H2O)] [3-dpye = N,N'-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,2-ethane, 3-dpyb = 3-dpyh = N,N'-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,6-hexane], in which two carboxyl groups and one amino group of 5-AIP ligand coordinate to the Cu(II) ions with a tri(monodentate) coordination mode [19]. While in this paper, the ligand 5-HAIP displays a bis(monodentate) bridging mode in complex 2 (Table 2): its amino group and one carboxyl group are simultaneously coordinated with Cu(II) ions, while another carboxyl group is protonated. The adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by the bridging 5-HAIP ligands to form a polymeric chain, as shown in Fig. 2b. The ligand 4-dpyb is not coordinated to Cu(II) ion (Table 2), which is different from that in complex 1. The π-π stacking interactions among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.61 Å, as well as the N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions between the nitrogen atom of amino group from 5-HAIP ligand and the carbonyl O5 atom of 4-dpyb ligand [N1…O5 = 2.955(5) Å] result in a 3 D supramolecular framework of complex 2 (see Fig. 2c).Crystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3)Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 3 consists of one Cu(II) ion, half a 4-dpyb ligand, one 2,6-PDA anion and one lattice water molecule. The Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a 2,6-PDA anion, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from one 4-dpyb ligand, and one carbonyl oxygen atom from another 4-dpyb ligand to give a CuO3N2 square-pyramidal arrangement [Cu1-O1 = 2.021(2), Cu1-O2 = 2.015(3), Cu1-O5 = 2.448(2), Cu1-N1 = 1.958(3), and Cu1-N2 = 1.896(3) Å], as shown in Fig. 3a. Each 2,6-PDA anion coordinates to one Cu(II) ion in a chelating coordination mode (Table 2). Then the Cu(II) ions are connected by 4-dpyb ligand with a μ4-bridging coordination mode (Table 2) to build a chain-like structure in complex 3 (Fig. 3b). The adjacent chains are packed into a 2 D supramolecular structure by π-π stacking interaction among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.69Å. Finally, the neighboring supramolecular layers are linked by the hydrogen bonding interactions to construct a 3 D supramolecular network. The C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the carbon atom (C11) from 2,6-PDA and the oxygen atom O3 from carboxyl group of 2,6-PDA with C(11)-H(11A)⋅⋅⋅O(3) distance of 3.266 Å.Thermal PropertiesTo estimate the stabilities of complexes 1-3, TG analyses are performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the temperature range of 30-700 °C, as shown in Fig. 4. The TG curves of complexes 1 and 3 show two weight loss steps. The first one should be assigned to the loss of water molecules 6.7 % (calcd. 6.3 %) in 1 and 4.7 % (calcd. 4.6 %) in 3. The second one occurs about 275 °C for 1 and 260 °C for 3, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of the organic ligands. The remaining weight 13.7 % for 1 or 19.6 % for 3 is in agreement with the percentage of Cu and O components (calcd.: 13.9 % for 1, 20.2 % for 3), which suggests that the final product is CuO. For complex 2, the TG curve only exhibits one obvious weight loss step. This weight loss observed at 315 °C may be attributed to the loss of the ligands 4-dpyb and 5-HAIP. The weight loss 88.6 % corresponds to the calculated value 88.9 %. The remaining weight 11.4 % is in agreement with the percentage 11.1 % of Cu and O components, implying that CuO is the thermal decomposition product of complex 2.Fluorescent PropertiesRecently, the fluorescent properties of a variety of transition metal complexes have been reported. The copper(II) complexes do not contain d10 metal centers, but a series of fluorescent copper(II) complexes have been reported [29, 30]. In order to investigate the potential applications of complexes 1-3, we have measured the fluorescent properties of complexes 1-3 in the solid state at room temperature. To understand the nature of these emission bands, we also examined the fluorescent behavior of the free 4-dpyb ligand. As shown in Fig. 5, the free 4-dpyb ligand displays a maximum fluorescent emission at 398 nm (λex = 320 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π-π* transitions. For complexes 1-3, upon excitation at 320 nm, the fluorescent emissions are observed at 395 nm for 1, 398 nm for 2, and 403 nm for 3, respectively. Compared with the 4-dpyb ligand, it is clear that a 3 nm blue-shift for 1 and a 5 nm red-shift for 3 can be observed, respectively. Similar to the reported copper(II) complexes with N-donor ligands, these phenomena may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition [19]. While the fluorescent emission of complex 2 is the same as the free 4-dpyb ligand, which may be due to the non-coordination mode of 4-dpyb in 2. The differences of fluorescent behaviors for complexes 1-3 are probably caused by the different coordination environment of Cu(II) ions with 4-dpyb ligands and final supramolecular structures of three complexes.ConclusionIn summary, three new copper(II) coordination complexes constructed by the flexible 4-dpyb ligand and three different aromatic dicarboxylates (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) have been hydrothermally synthesized, which represent examples of structural changes from a 2 D coordination polymeric network (for 1) to two kinds of chain-like structures (for 2 and 3). In complexes 1 and 3, the 4-dpyb serving as bridging ligands adopt the μ2- and the μ4-bridging coordination modes, respectively. While in 2, the 4-dpyb is not coordinated with Cu(II) ion. The results indicate that the different coordination modes of the flexible 4-dpyb ligands and three aromatic dicarboxylate anions play important roles in governing the final polymeric structures. These preliminary results in this work imply that the title complexes may be potential candidates for fluorescent materials. elements.content: Three new copper(II) complexes based on the flexible N,N’-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) and three different aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)], [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]·H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 2 D grid polymeric layer constructed by the [Cu-4-dpyb] chains and [Cu-5-MIP] chains, and the adjacent layers are further linked by hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 3 D supramolecular structure. Complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on the polymer chain [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n, in which the discrete 4-dpyb ligands are dispersed. Complex 3 represents a polymer chain based on the μ4-bridging 4-dpyb ligand, in which 2,6-PDA only serves as a terminal chelating ligand. For complex 3, the neighboring chains are extended into a 3 D supramolecular structure by hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking interactions. In these complexes, the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands 4-dpyb show the μ2-bridging mode (for 1), non-coordinated mode (for 2) and μ4-bridging mode (for 3), respectively, and three kinds of aromatic dicarboxylate anions (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) also adopt three different coordination modes. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes. In addition, the thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of complexes 1–3 have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new copper(II) complexes based on the flexible N,N'-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) and three different aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)], [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 2 D grid polymeric layer constructed by the [Cu-4-dpyb] chains and [Cu-5-MIP] chains, and the adjacent layers are further linked by hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 3 D supramolecular structure. Complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on the polymer chain [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n, in which the discrete 4-dpyb ligands are dispersed. Complex 3 represents a polymer chain based on the μ4-bridging 4-dpyb ligand, in which 2,6-PDA only serves as a terminal chelating ligand. For complex 3, the neighboring chains are extended into a 3 D supramolecular structure by hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking interactions. In these complexes, the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands 4-dpyb show the μ2-bridging mode (for 1), non-coordinated mode (for 2) and μ4-bridging mode (for 3), respectively, and three kinds of aromatic dicarboxylate anions (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) also adopt three different coordination modes. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes. In addition, the thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of complexes 1-3 have also been investigated.

elements.content: Three new 3 D supramolecular complexes based on 2 D polymer layers or 1 D chains, [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]·H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes.

Graphical Abstract

Three new 3 D supramolecular complexes based on 2 D polymer layers or 1 D chains, [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3), have been hydrothermally synthesized. The different coordination modes of ligands 4-dpyb and three dicarboxylates play important roles in the construction of final structures for title complexes.

elements.content: The rational design of transition metal complexes is of great importance for developing new crystalline materials owing to their intriguing architectures and topologies as well as their potential applications in gas storage/separation, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism [1–4]. Although a lot of such complexes have been prepared by the hydrothermal self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands, the controlled syntheses of these complexes are still facing many challenges due to many factors affecting the crystallization and structural construction in the hydrothermal conditions, such as organic ligands, reactants ratios, systematic pH values and reaction temperatures etc. [5–8]. Thereinto, organic ligands as bridging linkers are of the most critical factor for the formation of complexes because they greatly affect the coordination frameworks and specific topologies [9–11].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design of transition metal complexes is of great importance for developing new crystalline materials owing to their intriguing architectures and topologies as well as their potential applications in gas storage/separation, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism [1-4]. Although a lot of such complexes have been prepared by the hydrothermal self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands, the controlled syntheses of these complexes are still facing many challenges due to many factors affecting the crystallization and structural construction in the hydrothermal conditions, such as organic ligands, reactants ratios, systematic pH values and reaction temperatures etc. [5-8]. Thereinto, organic ligands as bridging linkers are of the most critical factor for the formation of complexes because they greatly affect the coordination frameworks and specific topologies [9-11].

elements.content: In the recent years, the employment of mixed ligands including neutral N-donor and anionic O-donor ligands has gradually become an effective approach [6, 12–15]. The flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand has been proved to be an excellent choice of the neutral N-donor ligand, by combining it with O-donor carboxylates ligands, a series of coordination complexes with diversified structures and interesting properties have been successfully prepared [16–19]. For example, Chen’s group has reported four new Ni(II) coordination complexes based on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands (N,N′-di(4-pyridyl)-adipoamide and N,N′-di(4-pyridyl)suberoamide) and three different bridging dicarboxylates, and all of the complexes exhibit various magnetic behaviors [18]. More recently, using the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand 3-dpyb (N,N′-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane), we have obtained a novel 3 D coordination complex, [Cu3(3-dpyb)(1,2-BDC)2(μ2-OH)2], which exhibits good photocatalytic activity for the degradation of methylene blue (MB) [19].
elements.clean_text: In the recent years, the employment of mixed ligands including neutral N-donor and anionic O-donor ligands has gradually become an effective approach [6, 12-15]. The flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand has been proved to be an excellent choice of the neutral N-donor ligand, by combining it with O-donor carboxylates ligands, a series of coordination complexes with diversified structures and interesting properties have been successfully prepared [16-19]. For example, Chen's group has reported four new Ni(II) coordination complexes based on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands (N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-adipoamide and N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)suberoamide) and three different bridging dicarboxylates, and all of the complexes exhibit various magnetic behaviors [18]. More recently, using the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand 3-dpyb (N,N'-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane), we have obtained a novel 3 D coordination complex, [Cu3(3-dpyb)(1,2-BDC)2(μ2-OH)2], which exhibits good photocatalytic activity for the degradation of methylene blue (MB) [19].

elements.content: As an extension of our study on the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands [19–22], in this work, we selected N,N′-bis(4-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,4-butane (4-dpyb) containing the flexible amide-(CH2)4-bridging group as the main ligand based on the following consideration: Its backbone -(CH2)4- can bend to satisfy the coordination requirements of metal centers, and its amide groups can provide additional coordination sites, which may lead to form intriguing coordination frameworks. In addition, the amide groups of 4-dpyb may be regarded as hydrogen bonding acceptors/or donors for building supramolecular networks. To our knowledge, the coordination complexes based on the mixed ligands of 4-dpyb and aromatic dicarboxylates have not been found up to now. So we introduce three aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)] into the copper(II)-4-dpyb system and generate three new complexes [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]·H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]·H2O (3). The thermal stabilities and the fluorescent properties of the three complexes have been examined.

In addition, the amide groups of 4-dpyb may be regarded as hydrogen bonding acceptors/or donors for building supramolecular networks. To our knowledge, the coordination complexes based on the mixed ligands of 4-dpyb and aromatic dicarboxylates have not been found up to now. So we introduce three aromatic dicarboxylic acids [5-methylisophthalic acid (5-H2MIP), 5-aminoisophthalic acid (5-H2AIP), pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2PDA)] into the copper(II)-4-dpyb system and generate three new complexes [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-MIP)(H2O)]⋅H2O (1), [Cu(4-dpyb)(5-HAIP)2] (2), [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3). The thermal stabilities and the fluorescent properties of the three complexes have been examined.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand 4-dpyb was prepared according to the reported literature [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Varian FT-IR 640 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) data for the complexes 1–3 were performed on a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence/phosphorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand 4-dpyb was prepared according to the reported literature [23]. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Varian FT-IR 640 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) data for the complexes 1-3 were performed on a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence/phosphorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of CuCl2·3H2O (0.051 g, 0.3 mmol), 4-dpyb (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), 5-H2MIP (0.027 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (12 mL) and NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 4 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: ca. 25 % based on Cu). Anal. for C25H28CuN4O8: calcd. C 52.08, H 4.90, N 9.72; found C 52.01, H 4.93, N 9.76 %. elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1–3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω and θ scan mode. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package [24, 25]. All non-hydrogen atoms were found and refined with anisotropic factors. The hydrogen atoms of the 4-dpyb ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. For complexes 2 and 3, carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C11 and C11′ in 2, C8 and C8′ in 3) were disordered. The hydrogen atoms of the incompletely deprotonated carboxyl groups for 5-HAIP anions in 2 and the hydrogen atoms of some carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C10, C11, C11′ in 2, C7, C8, C8′ in 3) could not be located, but were directly included in the final molecular formula. A summary of crystal data and structure refinements for three complexes was provided in Table 1. The coordination modes of copper(II) ions and ligands in complexes 1–3 were listed in Table 2. Selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table 3. CCDC reference numbers are 980117 (1), 968009 (2) and 980116 (3), respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray Crystallographic Study

X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1-3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω and θ scan mode. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package [24, 25]. All non-hydrogen atoms were found and refined with anisotropic factors. The hydrogen atoms of the 4-dpyb ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. For complexes 2 and 3, carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C11 and C11' in 2, C8 and C8' in 3) were disordered. The hydrogen atoms of the incompletely deprotonated carboxyl groups for 5-HAIP anions in 2 and the hydrogen atoms of some carbon atoms from the 4-dpyb ligands (C10, C11, C11' in 2, C7, C8, C8' in 3) could not be located, but were directly included in the final molecular formula. A summary of crystal data and structure refinements for three complexes was provided in Table 1. The coordination modes of copper(II) ions and ligands in complexes 1-3 were listed in Table 2. Selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table 3. CCDC reference numbers are 980117 (1), 968009 (2) and 980116 (3), respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 3 D supramolecular network based on a 2 D grid coordination polymer layer composed of bridging ligands 4-dpyb and 5-MIP. As illustrated in Fig. 1a, Cu1 ion is five-coordinated and adopts a distorted tetragonal pyramid geometry, being ligated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two 4-dpyb ligands with bond distances of 2.051(2) Å [Cu1–N1, Cu1–N2] and N1–Cu1–N2 angle of 175.07(8) °, three oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups of two 5-MIP anions and a coordinated water molecule [the bond lengths of Cu1–O range from 1.9506(16) to 2.2540(19) Å]. In complex 1, both carboxyl groups of the 5-H2MIP ligand are deprotonated and link two Cu(II) ions with monodentate coordination mode (see Table 2), which leads to the formation of a [Cu-5-MIP] linear chain. The μ2-bridging 4-dpyb ligands display two kinds of conformations (Table 2), which bridge two Cu(II) ions to build a [Cu-4-dpyb] chain with the non-bonding Cu···Cu distances of 20.191 Å (A-type) and 18.099 Å (B-type). The two pyridyl rings are parallel for 4-dpyb ligand. Two kinds of 4-dpyb ligands alternately connected the Cu(II) ions belonging to the adjacent [Cu-5-MIP] chains to construct a 2 D polymer layer, as shown in Fig. 1b. In 1, each Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four organic ligands (two 4-dpyb and two 5-MIP) and can simply be considered as a 4-connected node. Each 4-dpyb or 5-MIP ligating with two Cu(II) ions only can be regarded as a linear linker. Therefore, the 2 D network of 1 can be described as a well-known (4,4)-grid layer (Fig. 1c).

elements.content: X-ray analysis shows that complex 2 is a 3 D supramolecular network constructed from the polymeric chains [Cu(5-HAIP)2]n and discrete 4-dpyb ligands. The fundamental building unit of 2 is composed of one crystallographically independent Cu(II) ion, a discrete 4-dpyb ligand and a 5-HAIP anion. The coordination environment of Cu1 ion is shown in Fig. 2a. The Cu1 ion is tetra-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two amino groups of two 5-HAIP ligands, and two oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups belonging to two different 5-HAIP ligands, completing a quadrangle style. The bond distances and angles around the Cu1 are 1.904(2) Å for Cu1–O1 (Cu1–O1#1), 2.078(3) Å for Cu1–N1#2 (Cu1–N1#3), 180.0° for O1–Cu1–O1#1 (N1#2–Cu1–N1#3) and 88.26(10) – 91.74(10) ° for O–Cu1–N, respectively. So it is noted the O1–N1#2–Cu1–O1#1–N1#3 five-member unit is obviously perfectly planar.

elements.content: The 5-H2AIP ligand, as a dicarboxylate, possesses multiple potential coordination sites involving two carboxyl groups and one amino group, which may be more conducive to coordinate with metal ions in the metal–organic coordination frameworks. In addition, the 5-H2AIP could serve as hydrogen bonding donors or acceptors to build high-dimensional supramolecular networks. Recently, the 5-H2AIP ligand has been used as an auxiliary ligand combining with various N-donor ligands to construct intriguing structures and novel topologies [26, 27]. For example, Zheng’s group has obtained a 2 D (4,4) network [Co(5-AIP)(bix)]·H2O (bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl-methylene)-benzene), which shows a twofold parallel interpenetrating 2 D→2 D structure, and features a twofold interpenetrating cds hydrogen bonding network [28]. Our group has reported two 2 D metal–organic frameworks [Cu(3-dpye)0.5(5-AIP)(H2O)] and [Cu(3-dpyh)0.5(5-AIP)(H2O)] [3-dpye = N,N′-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,2-ethane, 3-dpyb = 3-dpyh = N,N′-bis(3-pyridinecarboxamide)-1,6-hexane], in which two carboxyl groups and one amino group of 5-AIP ligand coordinate to the Cu(II) ions with a tri(monodentate) coordination mode [19]. While in this paper, the ligand 5-HAIP displays a bis(monodentate) bridging mode in complex 2 (Table 2): its amino group and one carboxyl group are simultaneously coordinated with Cu(II) ions, while another carboxyl group is protonated. The adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by the bridging 5-HAIP ligands to form a polymeric chain, as shown in Fig. 2b. The ligand 4-dpyb is not coordinated to Cu(II) ion (Table 2), which is different from that in complex 1. The π–π stacking interactions among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.61 Å, as well as the N–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions between the nitrogen atom of amino group from 5-HAIP ligand and the carbonyl O5 atom of 4-dpyb ligand [N1…O5 = 2.955(5) Å] result in a 3 D supramolecular framework of complex 2 (see Fig. 2c).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 3 consists of one Cu(II) ion, half a 4-dpyb ligand, one 2,6-PDA anion and one lattice water molecule. The Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a 2,6-PDA anion, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from one 4-dpyb ligand, and one carbonyl oxygen atom from another 4-dpyb ligand to give a CuO3N2 square-pyramidal arrangement [Cu1–O1 = 2.021(2), Cu1–O2 = 2.015(3), Cu1–O5 = 2.448(2), Cu1–N1 = 1.958(3), and Cu1–N2 = 1.896(3) Å], as shown in Fig. 3a. Each 2,6-PDA anion coordinates to one Cu(II) ion in a chelating coordination mode (Table 2). Then the Cu(II) ions are connected by 4-dpyb ligand with a μ4-bridging coordination mode (Table 2) to build a chain-like structure in complex 3 (Fig. 3b). The adjacent chains are packed into a 2 D supramolecular structure by π-π stacking interaction among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.69Å. Finally, the neighboring supramolecular layers are linked by the hydrogen bonding interactions to construct a 3 D supramolecular network. The C–H···O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the carbon atom (C11) from 2,6-PDA and the oxygen atom O3 from carboxyl group of 2,6-PDA with C(11)–H(11A)···O(3) distance of 3.266 Å.

Crystal Structure of [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 3 consists of one Cu(II) ion, half a 4-dpyb ligand, one 2,6-PDA anion and one lattice water molecule. The Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a 2,6-PDA anion, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from one 4-dpyb ligand, and one carbonyl oxygen atom from another 4-dpyb ligand to give a CuO3N2 square-pyramidal arrangement [Cu1-O1 = 2.021(2), Cu1-O2 = 2.015(3), Cu1-O5 = 2.448(2), Cu1-N1 = 1.958(3), and Cu1-N2 = 1.896(3) Å], as shown in Fig. 3a. Each 2,6-PDA anion coordinates to one Cu(II) ion in a chelating coordination mode (Table 2). Then the Cu(II) ions are connected by 4-dpyb ligand with a μ4-bridging coordination mode (Table 2) to build a chain-like structure in complex 3 (Fig. 3b). The adjacent chains are packed into a 2 D supramolecular structure by π-π stacking interaction among the pyridyl rings of 4-dpyb ligands with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.69Å. Finally, the neighboring supramolecular layers are linked by the hydrogen bonding interactions to construct a 3 D supramolecular network. The C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interaction is formed between the carbon atom (C11) from 2,6-PDA and the oxygen atom O3 from carboxyl group of 2,6-PDA with C(11)-H(11A)⋅⋅⋅O(3) distance of 3.266 Å.

elements.content: To estimate the stabilities of complexes 1–3, TG analyses are performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in the temperature range of 30–700 °C, as shown in Fig. 4. The TG curves of complexes 1 and 3 show two weight loss steps. The first one should be assigned to the loss of water molecules 6.7 % (calcd. 6.3 %) in 1 and 4.7 % (calcd. 4.6 %) in 3. The second one occurs about 275 °C for 1 and 260 °C for 3, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of the organic ligands. The remaining weight 13.7 % for 1 or 19.6 % for 3 is in agreement with the percentage of Cu and O components (calcd.: 13.9 % for 1, 20.2 % for 3), which suggests that the final product is CuO. For complex 2, the TG curve only exhibits one obvious weight loss step. This weight loss observed at 315 °C may be attributed to the loss of the ligands 4-dpyb and 5-HAIP. The weight loss 88.6 % corresponds to the calculated value 88.9 %. The remaining weight 11.4 % is in agreement with the percentage 11.1 % of Cu and O components, implying that CuO is the thermal decomposition product of complex 2.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

To estimate the stabilities of complexes 1-3, TG analyses are performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the temperature range of 30-700 °C, as shown in Fig. 4. The TG curves of complexes 1 and 3 show two weight loss steps. The first one should be assigned to the loss of water molecules 6.7 % (calcd. 6.3 %) in 1 and 4.7 % (calcd. 4.6 %) in 3. The second one occurs about 275 °C for 1 and 260 °C for 3, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of the organic ligands. The remaining weight 13.7 % for 1 or 19.6 % for 3 is in agreement with the percentage of Cu and O components (calcd.: 13.9 % for 1, 20.2 % for 3), which suggests that the final product is CuO. For complex 2, the TG curve only exhibits one obvious weight loss step. This weight loss observed at 315 °C may be attributed to the loss of the ligands 4-dpyb and 5-HAIP. The weight loss 88.6 % corresponds to the calculated value 88.9 %. The remaining weight 11.4 % is in agreement with the percentage 11.1 % of Cu and O components, implying that CuO is the thermal decomposition product of complex 2.

elements.content: Recently, the fluorescent properties of a variety of transition metal complexes have been reported. The copper(II) complexes do not contain d10 metal centers, but a series of fluorescent copper(II) complexes have been reported [29, 30]. In order to investigate the potential applications of complexes 1–3, we have measured the fluorescent properties of complexes 1–3 in the solid state at room temperature. To understand the nature of these emission bands, we also examined the fluorescent behavior of the free 4-dpyb ligand. As shown in Fig. 5, the free 4-dpyb ligand displays a maximum fluorescent emission at 398 nm (λex = 320 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π–π* transitions. For complexes 1–3, upon excitation at 320 nm, the fluorescent emissions are observed at 395 nm for 1, 398 nm for 2, and 403 nm for 3, respectively. Compared with the 4-dpyb ligand, it is clear that a 3 nm blue-shift for 1 and a 5 nm red-shift for 3 can be observed, respectively. Similar to the reported copper(II) complexes with N-donor ligands, these phenomena may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition [19]. While the fluorescent emission of complex 2 is the same as the free 4-dpyb ligand, which may be due to the non-coordination mode of 4-dpyb in 2. The differences of fluorescent behaviors for complexes 1–3 are probably caused by the different coordination environment of Cu(II) ions with 4-dpyb ligands and final supramolecular structures of three complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties

Recently, the fluorescent properties of a variety of transition metal complexes have been reported. The copper(II) complexes do not contain d10 metal centers, but a series of fluorescent copper(II) complexes have been reported [29, 30]. In order to investigate the potential applications of complexes 1-3, we have measured the fluorescent properties of complexes 1-3 in the solid state at room temperature. To understand the nature of these emission bands, we also examined the fluorescent behavior of the free 4-dpyb ligand. As shown in Fig. 5, the free 4-dpyb ligand displays a maximum fluorescent emission at 398 nm (λex = 320 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π-π* transitions. For complexes 1-3, upon excitation at 320 nm, the fluorescent emissions are observed at 395 nm for 1, 398 nm for 2, and 403 nm for 3, respectively. Compared with the 4-dpyb ligand, it is clear that a 3 nm blue-shift for 1 and a 5 nm red-shift for 3 can be observed, respectively. Similar to the reported copper(II) complexes with N-donor ligands, these phenomena may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition [19]. While the fluorescent emission of complex 2 is the same as the free 4-dpyb ligand, which may be due to the non-coordination mode of 4-dpyb in 2. The differences of fluorescent behaviors for complexes 1-3 are probably caused by the different coordination environment of Cu(II) ions with 4-dpyb ligands and final supramolecular structures of three complexes.

elements.content: In summary, three new copper(II) coordination complexes constructed by the flexible 4-dpyb ligand and three different aromatic dicarboxylates (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) have been hydrothermally synthesized, which represent examples of structural changes from a 2 D coordination polymeric network (for 1) to two kinds of chain-like structures (for 2 and 3). In complexes 1 and 3, the 4-dpyb serving as bridging ligands adopt the μ2- and the μ4-bridging coordination modes, respectively. While in 2, the 4-dpyb is not coordinated with Cu(II) ion. The results indicate that the different coordination modes of the flexible 4-dpyb ligands and three aromatic dicarboxylate anions play important roles in governing the final polymeric structures. These preliminary results in this work imply that the title complexes may be potential candidates for fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three new copper(II) coordination complexes constructed by the flexible 4-dpyb ligand and three different aromatic dicarboxylates (5-MIP, 5-HAIP and 2,6-PDA) have been hydrothermally synthesized, which represent examples of structural changes from a 2 D coordination polymeric network (for 1) to two kinds of chain-like structures (for 2 and 3). In complexes 1 and 3, the 4-dpyb serving as bridging ligands adopt the μ2- and the μ4-bridging coordination modes, respectively. While in 2, the 4-dpyb is not coordinated with Cu(II) ion. The results indicate that the different coordination modes of the flexible 4-dpyb ligands and three aromatic dicarboxylate anions play important roles in governing the final polymeric structures. These preliminary results in this work imply that the title complexes may be potential candidates for fluorescent materials.

A mixture of CuCl2·3H2O (0.051 g, 0.3 mmol), 4-dpyb (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), 5-H2MIP (0.027 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (12 mL) and NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 4 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: ca. 25 % based on Cu). Anal. for C25H28CuN4O8: calcd. C 52.08, H 4.90, N 9.72; found C 52.01, H 4.93, N 9.76 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3388 w, 3284 w, 3070 w, 2928 w, 1653 s, 1617 s, 1572 s, 1547 s, 1497 m, 1420 m, 1353 s, 1224 m, 1194 w, 1107 s, 1071 m, 1024 w, 980 w, 858 s, 773 s, 727 s, 622 m, 519 w.

The synthesis method of 2 is similar to that of 1 except for ligand 5-H2AIP (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2MIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: ca. 33 % based on Cu). Anal. for C32H30CuN6O10: calcd. C 53.17, H 4.19, N 11.63; found C 53.19, H 4.15, N 11.60 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3373 m, 3278 m, 3079 w, 2938 w, 1711 m, 1628 s, 1614 s, 1567 s, 1541 s, 1478 m, 1429 m, 1380 s, 1368 m, 1327 m, 1214 m, 1186 m, 1077 m, 1048 m, 1025 w, 933 w, 868 s, 781 s, 715 s, 634 m, 522 w.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)<sub>0.5</sub>(2,6-PDA)]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

The synthesis method of 3 is similar to that of 2 except for ligand 2,6-H2PDA (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2AIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.016 g, 0.40 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. The synthesis method of 2 is similar to that of 1 except for ligand 5-H2AIP (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2MIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.018 g, 0.46 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: ca. 33 % based on Cu). Anal. for C32H30CuN6O10: calcd. C 53.17, H 4.19, N 11.63; found C 53.19, H 4.15, N 11.60 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3373 m, 3278 m, 3079 w, 2938 w, 1711 m, 1628 s, 1614 s, 1567 s, 1541 s, 1478 m, 1429 m, 1380 s, 1368 m, 1327 m, 1214 m, 1186 m, 1077 m, 1048 m, 1025 w, 933 w, 868 s, 781 s, 715 s, 634 m, 522 w.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-dpyb)0.5(2,6-PDA)]⋅H2O (3)

The synthesis method of 3 is similar to that of 2 except for ligand 2,6-H2PDA (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) as the substitute of 5-H2AIP, and the different amount of NaOH (0.016 g, 0.40 mmol) was added to adjust the systematic pH. Blue block crystals of 3 were obtained (yield: ca. 37 % based on Cu). Anal. for C15H14CuN3O6: Calcd. C 45.47, H 3.57, N 10.61; found C 45.41, H 3.59, N 10.67 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν = 3428 w, 3081 w, 2948 w, 1658 m, 1622 s, 1672 w, 1430 m, 1367 s, 1349 m, 1298 w, 1107 s, 912 w, 859 m, 786 s, 737 m, 620 s, 525 w.

cln_elements.content:
To estimate the stabilities of complexes 1–3, TG analyses are performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in the temperature range of 30–700 °C, as shown in Fig. 4. The TG curves of complexes 1 and 3 show two weight loss steps. The first one should be assigned to the loss of water molecules 6.7 % (calcd. 6.3 %) in 1 and 4.7 % (calcd. 4.6 %) in 3. The second one occurs about 275 °C for 1 and 260 °C for 3, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of the organic ligands. The remaining weight 13.7 % for 1 or 19.6 % for 3 is in agreement with the percentage of Cu and O components (calcd.: 13.9 % for 1, 20.2 % for 3), which suggests that the final product is CuO. For complex 2, the TG curve only exhibits one obvious weight loss step. This weight loss observed at 315 °C may be attributed to the loss of the ligands 4-dpyb and 5-HAIP. The weight loss 88.6 % corresponds to the calculated value 88.9 %. The remaining weight 11.4 % is in agreement with the percentage 11.1 % of Cu and O components, implying that CuO is the thermal decomposition product of complex 2.

Fluorescent Properties

Recently, the fluorescent properties of a variety of transition metal complexes have been reported. The copper(II) complexes do not contain d10 metal centers, but a series of fluorescent copper(II) complexes have been reported [29, 30]. In order to investigate the potential applications of complexes 1–3, we have measured the fluorescent properties of complexes 1–3 in the solid state at room temperature. To understand the nature of these emission bands, we also examined the fluorescent behavior of the free 4-dpyb ligand. As shown in Fig. 5, the free 4-dpyb ligand displays a maximum fluorescent emission at 398 nm (λex = 320 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π–π* transitions. For complexes 1–3, upon excitation at 320 nm, the fluorescent emissions are observed at 395 nm for 1, 398 nm for 2, and 403 nm for 3, respectively. Compared with the 4-dpyb ligand, it is clear that a 3 nm blue-shift for 1 and a 5 nm red-shift for 3 can be observed, respectively. Similar to the reported copper(II) complexes with N-donor ligands, these phenomena may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition [19]. While the fluorescent emission of complex 2 is the same as the free 4-dpyb ligand, which may be due to the non-coordination mode of 4-dpyb in 2. The differences of fluorescent behaviors for complexes 1–3 are probably caused by the different coordination environment of Cu(II) ions with 4-dpyb ligands and final supramolecular structures of three complexes.
